title: 112_hr3563
content: The Act may be cited as the "Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012". Congress acknowledges the availability of technologies to improve public alert systems, highlighting benefits such as enhanced security, rapid dissemination, remote notifications, targeted delivery, and use of homeland security grants for modernization. Testing the effectiveness of these enhancements is deemed necessary. The need to test diverse communication modes for public alerts, modernize Federal warning capabilities, and establish an integrated national network for reliable emergency alerts is recognized. SEC. 526 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 introduces the National Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization. This aims to enhance Federal warning capabilities and establish a reliable national network for emergency alerts. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 introduces the National Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization, aiming to enhance Federal warning capabilities and establish a reliable national network for emergency alerts. The Secretary is required to modernize and implement the national integrated public alert and warning system, including establishing common alerting and warning protocols and the capability to adapt dissemination based on geographic location and risks. The National Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization requires the system to alert individuals with disabilities and access needs, conduct training and tests, and provide ongoing training for stakeholders using advanced technologies. The National Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization mandates the use of the National Terrorism Advisory System for transmitting messages, conducting nationwide tests every 3 years, and collaborating with various stakeholders to enhance alert capabilities. The system must incorporate diverse modes for disseminating homeland security information. The National Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization requires the dissemination of homeland security information through warning messages to the public. It should be adaptable to future technologies, resilient against terrorism, promote partnerships for coordination, provide accessible alerts to all affected populations, improve alert reception in remote areas, and ensure protection mechanisms. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 establishes an Advisory Committee to ensure the protection of individual privacy and improve alert reception in remote areas. The committee includes members such as the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Advisory Committee established by the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 includes members appointed by the Secretary, such as representatives of State and local governments, the Assistant Secretary for Communications and Information of the Department of Commerce, and the Under Secretary for Science and Technology of the Department of Homeland Security. The Advisory Committee for the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 includes representatives from various organizations, including emergency management agencies, response providers, communication providers, federally recognized Indian tribes, national Indian organizations, and individuals with technical expertise in communications services. The Advisory Committee for the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 includes representatives from various organizations such as emergency management agencies, communication providers, broadcasting, cellular, cable, and satellite industries, as well as national organizations representing individuals with disabilities and the elderly. The Advisory Committee for the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 includes representatives from various organizations such as emergency management agencies, communication providers, broadcasting, cellular, cable, and satellite industries, as well as national organizations representing individuals with disabilities, the elderly, and educational institutions. The Secretary (or designee) serves as the Chairperson of the Advisory Committee, and the initial meeting must occur within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Advisory Committee for the Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 meets annually, with open meetings noticed 14 days in advance. The Committee may adopt rules and consult with nonmembers on new technology. The Advisory Committee considers new technology from various sources for the public alert and warning system. They develop recommendations for improving the system, including protocols, standards, and operating procedures. The Advisory Committee assesses the public alert and warning system, identifies accomplishments and deficiencies, and makes recommendations for increasing participation and improving the system's capabilities. The public alert and warning system should be capable of alerting individuals with disabilities, limited English proficiency, and incorporate multiple communication technologies. It should also adapt to future technologies and encourage proper use by State and local governments through training programs. The public alert and warning system should reach the largest affected population, promote partnerships for community preparedness, involve underserved communities, and provide redundant alert mechanisms where possible. The Advisory Committee will submit annual reports to the Secretary with recommendations, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Advisory Committee. A report must be submitted one year after the system is fully functional. The Secretary must submit a report every six months to the Committees on Homeland Security regarding the functionality and performance of the integrated public alert and warning system. This report includes findings from the Advisory Committee, an assessment of system accomplishments and deficiencies, recommendations for improvements, and information on disseminating homeland security information. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations totaling $13,400,000 for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2017 is granted to the Secretary for implementing this section. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the specified Act. Sec. 526 of the Act focuses on the modernization of the national integrated public alert and warning system. It clarifies that the Act does not impact the authority of specific departments and agencies. Additionally, it amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include improving public alert and warning capabilities as part of homeland security grants.
